', 'Germany[edit]': 'With at least 184 deaths,[9] the floods are the deadliest natural disaster in Germany since the North Sea flood of 1962. [46] It was considered unlikely that the number of deaths would rise that high,[47] and while on 19 July the exact number of missing persons remained unclear, a search was ongoing for at least 150 people. [49] During the floods, 135 people died in Rhineland-Palatinate (all of whom were in the district of Ahrweiler),[9] 47 in North Rhine-Westphalia (twenty-seven of whom in Euskirchen),[9] and two in Bavaria. [9] Four firefighters were among the dead. [55] Some of the worst damage from the flood was in the district of Ahrweiler, Rhineland-Palatinate, where the river Ahr rose, destroying many buildings and causing at least 110 deaths. [57] The flooding here was the worst since 1910 when up to 200 people were killed in flash flooding. [63] In Blessem, floodwaters of the Erft river inundated a quarry on 16 July, leading to a major landslide with several people possibly dead.  Berchtesgadener Ache, where at least one person died.  In Trentino-Alto Adige, a fallen tree damaged a cable car and several roads were damaged, and in Veneto one person died. [95][96] Two people were killed by floods in Satu Mare and Iași. [103]', 'Response[edit]': 'German Chancellor Angela Merkel said she was "shocked by the catastrophe that so many people in the flood areas have to endure" and that her "sympathy goes out to the families of the dead and missing. "[104] Malu Dreyer, the minister-president of the Rhineland-Palatinate state, told the regional parliament: "There are people dead, there are people missing, there are many who are still in danger. [128] Dieter Gerten, a researcher from the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research, characterised the magnitude of the floods and other extreme weather events as exceeding predictions from current climate change models, noting that the abrupt increase in the frequency and intensity of extreme weather may indicate that a tipping point has been crossed.

Death_text.7: [11] The heat wave also caused extensive damage to agriculture across the region, resulting in substantial loss of crop yield and the death of 651,000 farm animals. [4] The death toll exceeded 1,400 people, with at least 808 estimated in western Canada. [2] The Chief Coroner of British Columbia reported that 619 deaths were recorded due to heat exposure in the week from June\xa025 to July 1. [13] Confirmed deaths in the United States include at least 116 in Oregon (of which 72\xa0are in Multnomah County, which includes Portland),[14] at least 112 in Washington[15] and one death in Idaho;[16] An analysis by The New York Times suggests that around 600 excess deaths occurred the week the heat wave passed through Washington and Oregon. ', 'Canada[edit]': "The heat wave was the deadliest weather event in Canadian history. [102] Over 1,000 deaths occurred due to the direct consequences of the heat wave (such as hyperthermia).  Most of the deaths occurred in Canada – about 600 more deaths than usual were noted in British Columbia and 66 in Alberta. [103][104] Although excess death measurements are not guaranteed to be caused by a specific event, the Chief Coroner of British Columbia stated that 569 casualties could be attributed to heat, and that in the prior five years, only three heat-related casualties had been registered. [105] A later report put the heat-related death toll at 619. [13] A disproportionate number of heat-related deaths during the 2021 heat wave occurred in government-funded or licensed buildings such as long-term care facilities. [106] Of the total heat-wave-related deaths, 47 people died in community living, assisted living or long-term care facilities.  Further, 62 people died from heat exposure in social housing run or funded by the provincial government.  Eight individuals who lived at Vancouver Mental Health and Substance use housing died. [67][68]', 'United States[edit]': "In the United States, the death toll was lower but still in the hundreds: at least 116 deaths with confirmed heat-related causes in Oregon,[14] at least 112\xa0in Washington[15] and one in Idaho. [16] The New York Times analysis suggested that almost 450 excess deaths in Washington and 160 deaths in Oregon occurred during the heat wave. [3] On July\xa013,\xa02021, Multnomah County, Oregon published an analysis which found that a majority of deaths occurred in households which had no air conditioning or had only fans. [115] Some deaths also occurred among those seeking cooling in the Pacific Northwest's rivers. [100]', 'Deaths and injuries[edit]': '', 'Impact[edit]': '', 'Air conditioning[edit]': "The heat wave was a problem for major cities in the Northwest due to a lack of air conditioning. [143] Similarly, numerous grocers were forced to shut down aisles and halt the sale of perishable goods or use plastic sheets as impromptu thermal shields, as refrigeration units failed under the load.  Paul, Oregon, died while at work, Oregon OSHA faced calls to enforce safety rules for dealing with the heat wave, which had been first drafted in May. [176] The fire damaged roads, telecommunication and power facilities as well as the railway that comes through the settlement;[177] and two people were killed sheltering from the flames.  On the Pacific shore, temperatures in the intertidal zone reached up to 122\xa0°F (50\xa0°C) and more than a billion seashore animals, like clams, barnacles and oysters, died as a result of heat wave, impacting water quality. [200] The deaths also impacted seafood producers, who faced losses of produce as it baked in the heatwave and started rotting. [162] Fish kill, however, was not prevented in Alberta and appeared earlier than expected. [205] In Seattle, nearly a hundred juvenile terns, whose nests were on top of an industrial building, died when they plunged to the pavement below, presumably trying to escape the heat - those that survived were treated for burns.

Death_text.10: {'Contents': '', '2022 European heatwaves': ' From June to August 2022, persistent heatwaves affected parts of Europe, causing evacuations and killing tens of thousands.  These heat waves were the deadliest meteorological events in 2022. [12] Eurostat reported that the European Union saw 53,000 excess deaths in July, some of which may have occurred because of the heat wave.  The excess death rate was several times higher than in July 2020 or July 2021, a statistic notable due to the COVID-19 pandemic having taken place in Europe during those years. [19][20]', 'By country[edit]': 'The total number of deaths confirmed was 24,501 reported by the respective countries.  A statistical framework was paired against historical meteorological records to observe the trend of deaths.  The researchers said that they used weekly mortality data to develop their model which may not allow for short-term changes and hence may underestimate the actual number of deaths.  Countries around the Mediterranean Sea, especially Italy, Spain, Portugal and Greece, experienced higher death rates. [38] In November 2022, Reuters stated that there were 20,000 "excess" deaths recorded; deaths which officials did not directly attribute to heat but may be heat-induced. [39] In November 2023, the Barcelona Institute for Global Health revised their number to over 70,000 "excess" deaths after developing a new method to calculate the mortality rate. [46] There were an estimated 419 excess deaths across Austria. [177] On 15 July, the UKHSA increased the Heatwave Alert Level to 4, "illness and death occurring among the fit and healthyâ€”and not just in high-risk groups". [185] At least ten people died in water-related incidents and the London Fire Brigade declared a major incident after several fires broke out across the capital as a result of the heatwave. [188][189] In total, there were about 3,200 heat-related deaths in the UK, 2,800 of whom were above the age of 65. [63]', 'Deaths[edit]': 'The Robert Koch Institute put the death toll of the heatwaves at over 4,500. [100] A glacier collapse on the mountain of Marmolada on 4 July killed eleven, and was attributed to the abnormally warm temperatures. [102] In total, an estimated 18,010 excess deaths were reported due to the heat wave. [123] On 22 June, a one-year-old boy mistakenly left in a car died in Szczecin. [29] On 24 June, a man died in the queue of cars at the Polish-Ukrainian border by suspected overheating. [30] On 26 June in PÅ‚oÅ„sk, a man died from suspected sunstroke. [125] A pilot died when his waterbombing plane crashed in Vila Nova de Foz CÃ´a while combating wildfires in the region. [126] At least 238 people died because of the heat,[127] with 187 injuries. [128] According to the Portuguese Health Ministry, the heatwave killed 1,063 people between 7 and 18 July.  A further three people â€“ two firefighters and a civilian â€“ were killed in wildfires.

Death_text.16: {'Contents': '', 'Tropical Storm Erika': " Tropical Storm Erika was one of the deadliest and most destructive natural disasters in Dominica since Hurricane David in 1979.  All told, 30\xa0people died across the island in the nation's worst disaster since Hurricane David.  Five people died in Haiti, four from a weather-related traffic accident and one from a landslide. [17] Four persons died and eleven others were hospitalized in Léogâne, when a truck crashed into a bus on rain-slicked roads and exploded. [33] A fifth death occurred during a landslide in Port-au-Prince. [55] A total of 30\xa0people were killed,[2] 20\xa0others were injured, and 574\xa0people were left homeless. [64] One person was killed during a mudslide and one building collapsed in the city. [66][67] Twenty people died or were presumed dead in the village, accounting for two-thirds of the deaths attributed to Erika in Dominica. [127] A total of 65\xa0fatalities have been confirmed across the island, including 34 who are missing and presumed to be dead.

[3]', 'Impact by country[edit]': '', 'Rwanda[edit]': 'Heavy rain, lighting and thunderstorms affected the country between 2 and 4 March, causing 5 fatalities, with floods reported in Kigali and Southern provinces.  Two people died in flooding in Ruhango district, Southern Province and one person in Gasabo District, Kigali Province.  One person also died as a result of lightning strikes in Rulindo district, Northern Province and another one in Nyanza District, Southern Province.  On 7 March 5 people died after heavy rain caused a river to overflow and flood a cave in Nyamagabe district in Southern Province. [4][5] In April, 6 people died after heavy rain triggered landslides in Gicumbi district in Northern Province.  Heavy rain also affected parts of Eastern province 19 and 20 April where media said at least 3 people had died in separate flood incidents in Gatsibo district. [6] Heavy rain across the country from 1 to 3 May caused severe damages and 8 fatalities.  70 people have died in floods and landslides after torrential rain. [7]', 'Kenya[edit]': "237 people have died in flooding in Kenya in April and May while over 100,000 have been displaced. [10] In April 2020, extreme heavy rains caused landslide in West Pokot and Elgeyo Marakwet Counties which lead to death of 19 people, missing people, homes destroyed and dead of livestock.  16 people have died, 546,103 affected and 216,895 displaced. [12][13] In addition five people died when the rain caused a house to collapse on 11 May. [15] 1 person died and 280 were displaced after severe weather in Burundi during the period 2 to 8 March. [16]', 'Djibouti[edit]': '8 people have died in flash flooding in Djibouti. [17][18]', 'Ethiopia[edit]': 'As many as 12 people are thought to have died in a landslide triggered by heavy rain in Ethiopia.  Eight people died in Gamo zone in a period 11 to 18 April.  Flash floods on 24 April left at least 4 people dead in Dire Dawa. [19] On 29 May landslide killed 10 people in Gamo Zone.  Four people are thought to have died in the floods, with a further 3 people missing. \nSevere flooding and landslides occurred in Rubanda District, where 2 people have died and 31 houses have been destroyed.  At least person reportedly died in the floods. [21] On 21 May, 8 persons perished in new flash floods. [22]', 'Democratic Republic of the Congo[edit]': '44 people died, 200 were injured, while 64,000 were homeless in flooding in South Kivu Province.  Two fatalities were reported in Arumeru District, Arusha Region, where at least 50 homes have been destroyed.

Death_text.23: {'Contents': '', 'Tropical Storm Matthew (2010)': ' Tropical Storm Matthew was a weak but deadly and destructive tropical cyclone which made landfall in Central America during the 2010 Atlantic hurricane season.  Eight people were killed by the storm in Venezuela, and at least 100 people have been confirmed dead throughout Central America and southern Mexico. [5] In Caracas, Venezuela, heavy rains associated with Matthew triggered significant flooding that destroyed several homes, killing at least seven people.  At least 69 deaths have been confirmed throughout Central America; Nicaragua reported at least 66 fatalities, while three people were confirmed dead in El Salvador.  There have been no reports of deaths or injuries as a result of Matthew in the country. [35] Throughout the country, 66 people were reported dead as a result of heavy rainfalls associated with Matthew. [38] Throughout Mexico, at least 32 people have died due to several mudslides. [45] It was later advised that eleven people were missing, and no fatalities had been initially confirmed; however, up to six people were confirmed dead several days later, finalizing the death toll.

Death_text.29: {'Contents': '', 'Typhoon Phanfone': ' Typhoon Phanfone, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Ursula, was a strong and deadly tropical cyclone which traversed the Philippines on Christmas Eve and Christmas Day in 2019, the first typhoon to do so since Nock-ten in 2016.  The total fatalities of the said typhoon is 50 deaths (with 55 people missing, and over 300 injured) and the damages is at $67. [19] Five fishermen were reported missing and a 70-year-old man died after his house was swept away and as a result, he drowned.  As of December 27, 2019, there are at least 28 confirmed fatalities according to the Philippines Disaster Agency, including a 13-year-old boy who was electrocuted.

[55] There were four storm-related deaths in Cuba, while about 750\xa0homes, 7,900 acres (3,200\xa0ha) of crops,[54] and numerous bridges suffered flood damage. Eight deaths were reported in Atlantic Canada, while insured losses alone reached $800\xa0million, making the remnants of Fiona the costliest weather disaster in the region's history. [46] Ian also caused five deaths in Cuba. [31] An estimated 150\xa0fatalities occurred in Florida, with 36\xa0of the direct deaths reported in Lee County.  Ian also left five fatalities in North Carolina and one in Virginia, all due to indirect causes.  There were 54\xa0indirect flood fatalities in Venezuela. [91] Altogether, there were at least 89\xa0Julia-related fatalities: 54\xa0in Venezuela, 14\xa0in Guatemala, 10\xa0in El Salvador, 5\xa0in Nicaragua, 4\xa0in Honduras, and 2\xa0in Panama.  Additionally, three storm-related fatalities were reported in Chiapas: one in Pichucalco and two in Juárez. Death_text.82: {'Contents': '', 'Tropical Storm Matthew (2010)': ' Tropical Storm Matthew was a weak but deadly and destructive tropical cyclone which made landfall in Central America during the 2010 Atlantic hurricane season.  Eight people were killed by the storm in Venezuela, and at least 100 people have been confirmed dead throughout Central America and southern Mexico. [5] In Caracas, Venezuela, heavy rains associated with Matthew triggered significant flooding that destroyed several homes, killing at least seven people.  At least 69 deaths have been confirmed throughout Central America; Nicaragua reported at least 66 fatalities, while three people were confirmed dead in El Salvador.  There have been no reports of deaths or injuries as a result of Matthew in the country. [35] Throughout the country, 66 people were reported dead as a result of heavy rainfalls associated with Matthew. [38] Throughout Mexico, at least 32 people have died due to several mudslides. [45] It was later advised that eleven people were missing, and no fatalities had been initially confirmed; however, up to six people were confirmed dead several days later, finalizing the death toll.
